div1.p: Lyons lists the copies of Walter Reed items that have been selected from among those sent by Hench to be used in the Hall of Fame.

div1.head: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, April 9, 1948
div1.opener:
Every American is a shareholder in the Hall of Fame
HALL OF FAME : NEW YORK UNIVERSITY
I MADISON AVENUE · NEW YORK IO, N. Y.
Telephone: MURRAY HILL 3-4469
9 April 1948

Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I am just about coming out from under the great
deal of material which you were good enough to send to us
for possible use in the program, and after a long session
with Dr. Angell, in which we carefully considered every
piece of material on its own merit, we have decided to
use the following:
1. The reproduction of the birthplace--In this
instance we are using not the copy which you were good
enough to send, but a photostat which we received from the
Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, which is larger and
has a few more interesting details. When our printer has
made his cut, we shall be pleased to turn this photograph
over to you for your archives, or procure another copy
from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for you.
2. The photostat of Camp Lazear, the experimental
sanitary station near Quemados, Cuba. (Your No. 6a). You
say this was procured from the United States Army Medical
Museum of the Surgeon General's Library in Washington. I
assume, therefore, that the courtesy line should read “By
courtesy of U. S. Medical Museum, etc.”
yes
3. The photograph showing the remains of building
No. 1 taken in Cuba by you in March 1948, and the little
smoke stack of building No. 1. (Your No. 11b) Inasmuch
as you yourself took this photograph, we shall run the
courtesy line as follows: “By courtesy of Dr. Philip S.
Hench, Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minnesota.” If you do not
approve of this wording, please give me your own suggestions.
Very small
print so as
not to detract
from photo
yes
Dr. Philip S. Hench
-2-
April 9, 1948
4. The photostat of the wood cut (your No. 3C)
which you procured from the Bettmannarchives. I communicated
with Dr. Bettmann and I have persuaded him to permit us to
use this gratis, as well as the photostat of the “Exodus
from Newport News caused by the Yellow Fever Outbreak”
(your No. 3d), of course giving him the courtesy line.
yes
5. The Reed photograph while he was en route to
Cuba in 1900 to do his yellow fever work. (Your No. 5b)
I understand you procured this photograph from Mrs. Reed.
I assume you mean the widow. If I am wrong, please advise
me and also tell me whether I am to say “By courtesy of
Mrs.Walter Reed” or “By courtesy of Dr. Philip S. Hench.”
Nice to know
still leaving
both? ask
gen Reed
6. The photographs of Lazear, Carroll, Agramonte
and Finlay (Your No. 25), and with these photographs, perhaps,
the Walter Reed stamp for which I have written today to the
Postmaster General in Washington. These photographs, to-
gether with the stamp and the full length photograph of Reed
in civilian clothes will make an interesting page. I hope
you will agree with us.
7. Walter Reed General Hospital--As I told you
before, we received a very fine copy from the Metropolitan
Life Insurance Company, and we shall be happy to turn this
over to you, or get another copy for you for your own
archives after the program has been printed. In connection
with the reproduction of this photograph, will you be good
enough to tell me, if you can, without going to too much
trouble, when the Walter Reed General Hospital was established
in honor of Reed, in order that I may include this with the
photograph of the hospital.
8. A letter from General Reed to Major J. R. Kean
(now General Kean) dated September 6, 1900, which came to
us from the Surgeon General's office. This, of course, will
be credited to the Surgeon General's office. In any case,
I have written to Colonel McNinch, General Bliss's assistant,
asking him for the proper courtesy line.
jr?
anxious to
see

long have original

Dr. Philip S. Hench

April 9, 1948
9. Letter from Walter Reed to Mrs. Reed dated
October 6, 1900 (your No. 13). I have seen this letter, or
parts of it, in some of the books that I have gone through
on Reed, but I cannot remember which one offhand. However,
inasmuch as you sent it to us, would it not be proper for
me to merely say “By courtesy of Dr. Philip S. Hench”, or
do you think I will become involved with the publishers of
one of the volumes?
no place else
photograph
yes
10. Editorial of November 2, 1900 in the Washington
Post (your No. 21).
11. Letter from Walter Reed to Mrs. Reed dated
December 9, 1900. This photostat came to me from the
University of Virginia. To whom should this be credited
in the program? It is your material which I assume was
merely being housed at the University of Virginia. If I
am incorrect, and the University of Virginia should have the
credit line, please so advise me.
P S H.
12. Washington Post editorial of December 22, 1900
(your No. 22). This we are reproducing in its entirety.
13. Letter from Walter Reed to Mrs. Reed dated
December 31, 1900 (your No. 17). Who is to receive credit
for this letter? Of course it appears in Kelly's book, and
in several others, but here again since the letter is actually
in your possession, I suppose you should really have the
courtesy line.
no place else
photo
Mrs. Reed &
P S H?
14. Letter from Walter Reed to Dr. Howard dated
January 13, 1900 (really 1901)--your No. 20. Again, I have
seen this letter reproduced in several volumes but think
you should have the credit line inasmuch as you have the
original letter.
No, write
Mr Howard
15. Notes from “Walter Reed. A Memoir” by Walter D.
McCaw published by the Walter Reed Memorial Association in
1904. These notes give the details of the experiments that
were made and briefly sum up the principal conclusions of
the board of investigators.

And last, but not least, the insert of the Cornwell
painting which Wyeth is furnishing. Of course, the courtesy
line will appear for Wyeth giving them full credit.

In addition to all of the above, we are reproducing
on one page estimates of Reed by Dr. William H. Welch,
General Wood and General Gorgas. All of these are included
in the dedicatory address which General Kean made at the
dedication of the birthplace, and which appeared in “The
Military Surgeon.” I have written to Washington asking
for permission to reproduce parts of these appraisals.

medal all
out?

saw it.
But I get prize
Roll of Honor

I know this is a very long letter for you to wade
through, but you know how important it is to have these
courtesy lines appear and appear accurately, in order that
we may not become involved legally in any respect, and for
this reason I hope you will pardon this additional intrusion
upon your time and your good nature. I am now sending the
material to the printer to have the cuts made, and I would
therefore appreciate your kind response.

With every good wish to you, and my reiterated
thanks, believe me
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Bertha L. Lyons
